point-of-sale terminals fit into this process so normally when we go into a business we pay for some goods will
either interact with the terminal directly or we'll hand our card over to
the merchant once our card information has been read this will be passed to the
acquiring bank for the merchant at this point they don't actually know who our issuing Bank is so they'll ask the card
brands such as Visa MasterCard to determine this information once this has been passed you're issuing
Bank the check that you have the necessary funds to complete the transaction and carry out some flawed
checks if they're happy for you to go ahead they'll send the response back along the chain and you can complete the
payment if we take a look at what this looks like for a mobile point-of-sale terminal provider we can see that the
key difference is that merchant no longer has a direct relationship with the acquirer instead the mobile point of
sales terminal provider acts as a payment aggregator this means that they
will or won't assess risk at the same level as a traditional acquiring bank and they may also choose to mitigate
some of the risk in other ways for example contractually when you go to
make a transaction there is a list that broadly describes the types of operations from highest priority low to
lowest priority this list differs depending on the issuer the card brand
and potentially the geographic region as well but generally generally speaking we
can understand that certain payment types are more risky than others for example chip-and-pin is considered most
secure this is because there's a high level of assurance that the cardholder was present during the transaction
whereas something such as magstripe is considered low in its level of security this is because the magnetic
stripe on the back of the card can be cloned a signature can obviously be forged without much effort and there's
no signing of the transaction there's no cryptogram like modern transactions
next we need to understand that well generally speaking EMV has been adopted very successfully

Bluetooth is the main form of communication between the phone and the reader and the mobile application
therefore it's really important for us to have an understanding of how the protocol works so let's make a brief
overview of the protocol stack bluetooth can be roughly divided into two separate
areas so we have the host and the controller layers the Bluetooth profiles and Gatton acts deal with the actual
transfer of information then we have l2 cap which deals with the segmentation and reassembly of packets then we have
the host controller layer host controller interface or HCI which is the lowest level that we can directly
interact with without specialist equipment so this is commonly used for debugging by developers but if you're a
security researcher it's particularly helpful to have access to this because you can start to understand some of the
functions of the device then we have the link manager protocol which deals with pairing negotiation and encryption we
have baseband which is the last layer of framing before Bluetooth radio itself
when we talk about Bluetooth were actually talking about two different protocols Bluetooth classic and
Bluetooth low-energy Bluetooth classic uses Bluetooth profiles to communicate
with all of the devices that we looked at that use Bluetooth classic use RF
comm so what this does is it simulates a serial point or port between the reader
and the mobile application so this means we can send large amounts of data between the two devices on the other on
the other hand Bluetooth low-energy only allows for the small sending of data
this is used as a hierarchical structure under which services and characteristics
are defined each characteristic has a unique value and properties such as read
write and notify if you want to attack a Bluetooth device or just communicate
with it we obviously need to know what the address is made up of so the Bluetooth address is made up of three
main parts we have the non significant address part which isn't significant for any functions the upper address part and
lower address par the lower address part is present in every frame and its unique to the specific device the non
significant address part an upper adjust part is what is known as the organizationally unique ID or you owe
you I so if you know what this information is so if you have a range of these four vendors it's possible to sit
in to sit in a public place and identify potentially vulnerable devices a
Bluetooth network is also made up of a master and slave model so one master can
have up to seven slaves there are many different Bluetooth attack vectors but
we'll be focusing on two so the first is man in the middle or eavesdropping and the next is malicious device
manipulation so with eavesdropping you're trying to intercept the communication between the master and the
slave and decrypt the communication if you want to if you want to manipulate
the device maliciously you can just connect to the device but in order to carry out that kind of

man-in-the-middle attacks you require special istic equipment so the equipment
